thread.title: National service­ call for IT-savvy cyber warriors
thread.title_full: National service­ call for IT-savvy cyber warriors | Business Spectator

author: Sarah Martin
title: National service­ call for IT-savvy cyber warriors
text:
Online security threats are so extreme­ that the country should consider nationalising the industry and introducing national service­ for IT-savvy cyber warriors, an expert from the Australian ­Information Security Association says.
James Turner, a senior adviser for security firm IBRS, will tell an AISA conference in Adelaide today the country faces a dire skills shortage in the cyber sector that demands the consideration of “controversial” ideas.
While conceding the proposal is provocative, Mr Turner says nationalising the country’s managed security services should be considered given the growing threat and the need to share skills and knowledge.
“Let’s put it on the table because­, yes, it is extreme and controversial, and I am the first to admit that shared services has not got a good track record, but we need to be sharing resources comprehensively right now,” he says.
This could be achieved by expandi­ng the role of the Australian Cyber Security Centre that brings together the work of six securit­y agencies acting to prevent and disrupt online attacks, Mr Turner says.
In August, the ACSC warned that Australia was coming under “unrelenting” attack from online security threats, with the number of serious incidents more than tripling in three years and forecast to cost more than $1 billion in malicious damage from activity including crime and espionage.
“It doesn’t matter if it is a governm­ent agency or a bank or a health sector provider; whether it is government or private sector … we are all equally vulnerable and we need to respond as a community,’’ Mr Turner said­.
“We are standing on a burning platform right now, and if we don’t address this then we are in trouble.”
Mr Turner, who is also chairman of the Australian Inform­ation Security Association’s advocacy group, says that large organisations and government agencies are both struggling with skills shortages, with the pipeline of students still likely to fall short of demand.
Another option to address this skills gap could be to draft university students into cyber national service, or retrain veterans who had the require­d “militaristic thinking” to work in the field.
“Cyber national service is something we really need to be looking at,” Mr Turner said.
The government is under­taking a review of the country’s cyber security strategy, with a panel of industry leaders exam­ining how to make public and private­ networks more resilient to attacks.
This story was first published in The Australian Business Review.
